intro: Suaeda microphylla, commonly known as the desert sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing, mat-forming annual plant with small, fleshy leaves that help reduce water loss in its harsh environment. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its succulent leaves store water, allowing it to survive in dry conditions. Suaeda microphylla plays an important role in stabilizing sandy soils and supporting desert ecosystems.
